title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise
background: Age-related loss of skeletal muscle mass and function (sarcopenia) affects up to 25% of humans aged 65+ and over 40% of those ≥80 years old. Sarcopenia increases susceptibility to fatigue, weakness, and fall-related injuries, with compromised sarcolemmal integrity contributing to muscle deterioration.
objective: To determine if lifelong mild (8%) caloric restriction (CR) and CR plus voluntary wheel running (WR) could ameliorate age-related disruption of membrane scaffolding and signaling proteins, maintaining a healthy membrane environment in plantaris muscle fibers.
methods: Fischer-344 rats were divided into four groups: 24-month old adults fed ad libitum (OAL); 24-month old on 8% CR (OCR); 24-month old 8% CR + WR (OCRWR); and 6-month old sedentary adults fed ad libitum (YAL). Analysis included histochemical staining, immunohistochemistry for DGC proteins, western blot analysis of membrane repair proteins and Nox2 subunits, and muscle fiber cross-sectional area measurements.
results: Aging caused discontinuous membrane expression of DGC proteins (dystrophin, α-syntrophin, nNOS) and decreased Nox2 subunits. Membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexin A6, A2) significantly increased in OAL. Lifelong CR and CRWR protected against DGC disruption, maintained membrane repair proteins near YAL levels, and prevented Nox2 subunit loss. Both interventions partially prevented age-related decrease in fiber cross-sectional area.
conclusion: Lifelong mild caloric restriction and voluntary exercise are effective countermeasures against age-related alterations in the myofiber membrane environment, potentially preventing sarcopenia progression and maintaining muscle quality.

learning_notes.note: Lifelong mild caloric restriction (8%) combined with voluntary wheel running significantly attenuated age-related muscle fiber atrophy, with OCRWR rats showing 2778 μm² fiber cross-sectional area compared to 2264 μm² in sedentary aged rats, representing a 23% improvement in muscle preservation.

Aging caused discontinuous sarcolemmal patterning of key dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC) proteins including dystrophin, α-syntrophin, and nNOS, with nNOS showing 59% reduction in sarcolemmal localization in aged muscles, while CR and CRWR interventions maintained 94-101% higher sarcolemmal nNOS levels.

Membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexin A6, annexin A2) were significantly elevated in aged sedentary muscles, indicating increased membrane damage and repair cycles, while lifelong CR+WR maintained these proteins at near-young adult levels, suggesting protection against sarcolemmal damage.

NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits showed age-related reductions, with p47phox and p67phox decreasing significantly in sedentary aged muscles, while CR and CRWR interventions prevented this decline and maintained Nox2 subunits at levels comparable to young adults.

The combination of caloric restriction and exercise (OCRWR) provided superior protection compared to caloric restriction alone, particularly for membrane repair proteins where OCRWR maintained annexin A6 at control levels while OCR alone showed intermediate elevation.

This research was supported by NASA grant NNX12AR62G, indicating direct relevance to spaceflight applications and recognition of the importance of understanding muscle preservation mechanisms for long-duration missions.

The study design used 8% caloric restriction specifically because this level was found to be sufficient to encourage voluntary wheel running activity in aged rats, making it a practical intervention approach that could be translated to human spaceflight protocols.
